original: Beer, Waldemar, intendent, Visby, f. 31/7/84 i Stockholm av musikhandl. Georges B. o. Maria Sandahl. G. 15 m. sångerskan Walborg Granath. Barn: Henrik f. 15, Allan 18, Marie-Louise 20. — Stud:ex. 03, hand:s^k. 04. Anst. v. bank. i Niirnberg, Paris, London 11-14, sen. tur:- o. stud:res. i Skand. o. på kontin. Anst. i bank. i Sth-lm bl. a. som utrikeskorr. 04-11 o. 14-25, i A-B Nord. Resebureau i Sthlm 26-28, turistintendent i Gotl. tu-ristfören. o. Angf. A-B Gotland i Visby fr. 28. Ordf. i Västg. gille i Visby, v. ordf. i skidfrämj., omb :m. i scout-främj., •styr:led. i Sv. turisttraf :förb. i Sthim. Medarb. i fackpr. Hobbies: musik, grafik, turistisk litt. o. vestro-gothica.
translated: Beer, Waldemar, superintendent, Visby, born July 31, 1884 in Stockholm to music dealer Georges B. and Maria Sandahl. Married for 15 years to singer Walborg Granath. Children: Henrik, born in 1915, Allan in 1918, Marie-Louise in 1920. Waldemar completed his high school education in 1903 and took a commercial course in 1904. He worked for banks in Nuremberg, Paris, and London from 1911 to 1914, then traveled and studied in Scandinavia and on the continent. He worked for banks in Stockholm, including as a foreign correspondent, from 1904 to 1911 and from 1914 to 1925. From 1926 to 1928, he worked as a tourist superintendent for the Gotland Tourist Association and Angf. AB Gotland in Visby. He was chairman of the Västgötaland Guild in Visby, vice president of the Ski Promotion Association, and a member of the Scout Promotion Association and board of directors of the Swedish Tourist Traffic Association in Stockholm. He contributed to professional journals and had interests in music, graphics, tourist literature, and Westrogothic history.

worksFor.name: Gotland Tourist Association and Angf. AB Gotland

structured.description: Waldemar Beer was a Swedish superintendent who worked for banks in Europe and Stockholm. He also served as a tourist superintendent in Gotland and held various positions in different associations. He contributed to professional journals and enjoyed music, graphics, tourist literature, and Westrogothic history.
